title: Leveraging Temporal Dynamics of Document Content in Relevance Ranking

author: Jonathan Elsas, Language Technologies Institute, Carnegie Mellon University

segmentation: I'm John Elsys, PhD student at CMU.
I'll be presenting joint work with Susan Dumais at Microsoft Research on leveraging temporal dynamics of document content in relevance.
So first a quick outline of the talk talk a little bit about document dynamics on the web and how this has been studied in the past and what's really missing from some of this academic study.
Talk about our setting, which is looking at ranking and dynamic documents.
Describe the test collection and how we measure change across across time.
Document change across time.
And talk about two and present two ways that we leverage this kind of change in relevance ranking.
First document prior based on gross message measures of document change and also presented document representation that looks at term level change within the document.
So we all know the web is is dynamic.
Documents change all the time.
Some documents undergo somewhat gradual change over, say, 10 years.
Some documents go through very dramatic change over long periods of time.
And some some documents go undergo very dramatic change in only 10 minutes.
This is a page from Craigslist and the entire content changed in just 10 minutes.
So how is how is?
How is this change been studied previously?
Well, there's been studies looking at what types of page pages changed and how much, and how frequently how new content is added to the web, and new links are added.
There's been some work last year at Wisdom looking at change within the page at the block level or the.
Farm level.
And there's also been quite a bit of work looking at implications of the change in various information seeking tasks and browsing on having indexes support the version documents.
In in just in the index and how to set crawling policies based on based on how documents change.
But there really has been no academic study on how this change on the web.
Can affect ranking?
So that's what we aim to do here.
Will will look at these implications in two different areas.
First looking at gross measures of document change, so whether document changes and sort of on average how much it changes and how can we.
Can we learn anything about the quality of a page based on these gross change measures?
Well also look at ways to represent change at really the term level within the document.
Really ask the question.
Are there characteristics of the dynamic document content that indicates some content may be more or less important than other content?
So quickly I'll describe the test collection we use for these experiments.
We started with about 18,000 queries that it all been assessed for relevance corresponding to about 2 1/2 million judged documents.
These were assessed on A5 level relevant scale.
Each of these two and a half million documents were crawled weekly for 10 weeks, so we will refer to one of these crawls as a slice of our collection.
But the entire snapshot of every document over the 10 weeks is our is the document collection within these experiments.
We focus on navigational queries here, and we identify those queries based on the presence of at least one document judged perfect.
Typically there's just one, and when there's more than one, these are often pretty much equivalent pages.
So these queries we identify as navigational.
For fitting the parameters in our retrieval models, we split this queryset into TR.
Eating test sets.
So one of the one of the main reasons we focus on navigational queries is for ease of evaluation.
Here we make the assumption that, at least for these queries, the idea of relevance doesn't really change overtime.
It's more of a static.
If a page is relevant to the query at one point in time, it will be relevant across time.
How quickly I'll describe the method for measuring change.
Of a document in across different time slices, we use a technique called shingle printing which has been used quite a bit in the past, so I'll go over this somewhat quickly.

So we have our documents at two different time time snapshots here at T and T + 1 we take a moving window and move it over the content of the document and calculate a hash signature of the content in that window.
We move this window across the whole document in calculated series of these hashes and do the same for the document at all points in time.

These two sets of hash signatures are the shingle sets at time TI and I + 1, and by looking at the these elements of these sets that are the same or different at two different times, we get some sense of how much the document has changed overtime.
And our primary measure of change, then, is basically the average overlap overtime of these sets of subsequent slices in our collection.
So now remember, every document in your collection has been judged.
Has been judged with regard to some query on A5 level relevant scale and this is showing just binary change whether or not a document changes at all in our collection.
And on the Y axis and the relevance level on the X axis.
And we see that there really is a pretty clear correspondence between the relevance level and whether or.
How to document changes?
In fact, about 63% of those documents judged perfect in our collection had some underwent some change over the course of the collection, whereas on average just about 37% change.
Now that was looking at binary change.

Looking a little bit deeper of those documents that underwent any change we may want to see how much they changed, so this is showing this single difference measure on the Y axis, and again relevance level on the X axis.
And we can see again that there is a strong correspondence between relevance level and the amount of change.
So we've seen that more relevant documents are more likely to change and change to a greater degree than non relevant documents.
So we may wonder, can we favoring more dynamic documents in ranking something that may boost performance?
So now I'll describe how we do that.
Here.

We take a very straightforward language modeling approach to document scoring, so the score of a document given a query is proportional to some prior probability on that document, and the likelihood of generating a query from the documents.
And as our baseline model, we just use a uniform prior so all documents are treated equally regardless of their change characteristics.
Further, this is our static model.
We also introduced a change prior which scales with this single difference measure.
Parameterized here just to adjust the degree of scaling with this measure.
Now looking at.
The effect of this change prior on performance here I have on the Y axis I have the.
The percentage gain or loss in NDC G on the X axis.
We have the rank cutoff.
We see that higher ranks using this change prior really does give a significant boost iperf.
Formance we think there's a little bit of overfitting at the Top Rank, but we do see some potential in favoring dynamic documents in ranking.
So that work was looking at gross measures.
Measures have changed on average.
How much does a document change, or whether a document changes at all?
We may also want to look at the content of the document to understand which terms change in the document in which state is same.
And understand if there's characteristics of these dynamic terms that may be used in retrieve.
So to motivate this some, I'll use this slide.
This is actually from top wisdom last year and this shows.
Calling this a term longevity plot, this shows for a single page we have on the Y axis here.

All of the vocabulary in the page, overtime, and so a sample of those terms are shown here, but really, every sort of horizontal in this in this graph represents a single term, and on the X axis we have time.
And so when a term is present in the document at that point in time, we draw the part of the line, and when it's absent, we leave it blank.
And so this what this graph shows is towards the bottom.
These are terms that were present in the document at the beginning of.
At the beginning of this collection and as we go up, these are terms that enter the vocabulary later in the collection.
And the more sort of ink you see a cross.
Across the line indicates how consistently the term was in the vocabulary.
The document, so some terms like cooks are always present in this.
Document and other terms that have to do with sort of seasonal recipes come and go.

Looking at these a bit more closely again, we see these Long live terms like recipes and cooks have a lot of ink on the line corresponding to those terms, whereas shortly vocabulary is much less and we can see how these terms come and go as time goes on.
So we would like to do is identify terms that are transient and more permanent in the document overtime.
We take a fairly simple approach in this.
In this paper we identify shortly vocabulary that is present in less than 50% of the slices in our collection and Long live vocabulary.
This president, in almost all of the slices in our collection.
So when we model when we represent our document as.
A combination of short, medium and Long live vocabulary.

We can then change this query likelihood as rather than just generating the query from the document language model, we can model it as a mixture of language models between this long, medium and short.
Vocabulary and this allows us to differentially weight these two types of vocabulary.
So for some queries, maybe the long lived vocabulary would be more important, and for others this short lived more bursty vocabulary.
Maybe more important, we refer to this is our dynamic ranking model.
Now looking at the performance of this model, we see.
Be very consistent and significant improvements over the baseline model.
Remember, these are for these navigational queries and as it turns out, the parameters that.
That being most useful for these.
For these types of queries tended to favor the long term vocabulary, so make some sense.
So we presented two models for leveraging dynamic content in relevance ranking a query independent change prior that favored dynamic documents regardless of the query.
And when we presented a dynamic document representation which has the ability to differentially weight terms based on their dynamic characteristics overtime.
So we can of course.
Combine these two models and when we do we see.
Roughly, an additive improvement in performance.
So these these two methods really seem to be complementary methods for leveraging document dynamics.
So in this work we demonstrated that we know documents change and we demonstrated that we can use characteristics of those.
The dynamics within the document to improve retrieval performance.
We presented two complementary methods of leveraging change in ranking.
And the focus here was on these navigational queries, where we make the assumption that relevant stays consistent overtime.
There's current work looking at dynamic information needs and relevance that may shift overtime as current events change.
So stay tuned for for that.
Thanks.
I've got a lot of voice I. I'm curious, how would you deal with navigational text on the pages that never changes?
So the.
May not be relevant like everything, every every paper.
Harvard Site has a little business in the business, right?
Sure, so we didn't treat those any differently, right?
We didn't do any sort of template discovery in the pages to identify navigational versus more content text.
Those terms would definitely be in this long term language model.
Here really only affects things when those terms are also in the query, so.
Which 2.5 million?
So these were documents that were ranked highly in a commercial search engine, an were assessed for relevance.
For those 18,000 queries, yes.
As.
